body: It works by removing default="0"
merged, many thanks!

@thirdwing  
thanks for your advice.
 I have refered to #1085. 
The mxnet_0.5.tar.gz can be generated.
However, it can not pass the test phase and the following error is given:

C:\mxnet> R CMD INSTALL --no-multiarch R-package
- installing to library 'C:/Program Files/R/R-3.2.3/library'
- installing _source_ package 'mxnet' ...
  *\* libs
  make: Nothing to be done for `all'.
  nstalling to C:/Program Files/R/R-3.2.3/library/mxnet/libs/x64
  *\* R
  *\* demo
  *\* inst
  *\* preparing package for lazy loading
  *\* help
  **\* installing help indices
  *\* building package indices
  *\* installing vignettes
  *\* testing if installed package can be loaded

Error in namespaceExport(ns, exports) :
  undefined exports: mx.nd.max, mx.nd.min, mx.nd.sum
:

ERROR: loading failed
- removing 'C:/Program Files/R/R-3.2.3/library/mxnet'

Do I understand correctly that tweaking would require a substantial change of the whole library? I am willing to code new layers change internals a little bit, but I would like to know, how big the change would be?

I was thinking about the solution with padding, but I do not like it since the difference in sizes is quite big in my case.

Thank you very much for the answer.

1) use gcc. some people had difficulties with icc before
2) try `make clean_all && make`
did you install blas? is it in path? can you find the file cblas.h in your system any where? if not you need to install a version of blas.

`INFO:root:Start training with [gpu(0)]`
you trying to use gpu. change it to mx.cpu() instead.
could you check if your model weights changed?
Ok. I changed model.py to set write_req to null for inputs.

So I made some progress passing multiple apps/paths to `ADD_CFLAGS` as follows: 

`ADD_CFLAGS = -isysroot /Applications/Xcode.app/Contents/Developer/Platforms/MacOSX.platform/Developer/SDKs/MacOSX10.11.sdk -mmacosx-version-min=10.11 -I/usr/local/opt/openblas/include`

The error I'm getting now, near the end of compilation, is: 

```
/usr/local/include/c++/4.9.2/cstdio:42:19: fatal error: stdio.h: No such file or directory
 #include <stdio.h>
```

I attempted adding `-I/usr/local/include/c++/4.9.2/tr1`, which is where `stdio.h` is located, to `ADD_CFLAGS`, but this caused the compilation to error out right away. The installation seems to be looking for this header file in the `cstdio` subdirectory, but there's nothing in there on my machine. The relevant files are in `tr1`.

`USE_BLAS` set to `apple` and `openblas` doesn't seem to make a difference.
So to be clear, I solved what was going on with `cblas.h`. The trouble now is with `stdio.h`. Not sure if we should close here and open a separate issue?
the two steps have been done and still have the problem
This is due to cblas version is not compiled with fpic, consider switch to other blas version. such as openblas
you can do this by copy make/config.mk to root folder and modify the USE_BLAS option
hi, @piiswrong , thanks for reply. It seems this issue is related to the activation function.
Since this is a major refactor, bring in more reviewers @antinucleon @mli @sneakerkg

Here is the goal of the first PR:
- Make sure all the old code works, with assumption of dtype float32, and report failure when other types are inputed.
- (optional) Support a typecast op so we can cast types easily.

It is not necessary to upgrade all ops to support all types

Are you using the latest version?

Closing this issue and opening a new one related to stdio.h
I added NDArray.astype() for explicit type conversion. Copy on the same device will implicitly convert type if source and target have different type.
I have finished type support for most ops. One problem is divide by zero with integer types will cause core dump. How should we handle this more gracefully?
What's the performance before/after this change?

first nvidia-smi and cuda gpu numbering sometimes doesn't match. There is a mapping and you need to figure out your self.
second, could you show your GPU utilization?
To clarify, if I am currently using NDArrayIter on numpy arrays of 64 bit floats, will it work as intended? Or do they have to be 32 bit floats?
@jmschrei It will work. but the data will be converted to 32bit when feeding to the network.
Okay, thanks for the clarification!

Solved this one by installing command line tools, which you have to do from the command line with OSX Capitan as follows: 

`xcode-select --install`
It might be related to https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/1097

Possibly. Seemed like it could also be related to #1047. The same problem with python. The funny thing is that after running `git submodule foreach git pull origin master` in root the line `MLC_REGISTER_DATA_PARSER(uint32_t, csv, data::CreateCSVParser<uint32_t>);` does indeed show up at the end of `dmlc-core/src/data.cc`. So the data type is definitely defined, but the R/python integrations I've been playing with aren't finding it. @tqchen suggested running make clean, but wasn't specific about what subfolder(s). I've run make clean across the subfolders of various levels in dmlc-core, as well as root, and that hasn't solved the problem either. Apparently this worked for @alzmcr, though. Any repo contributors have some guidance?

@thirdwing 
Now it works. Thanks.
The libmxnet.dll was produced several days ago, while the codes in R-package in latest state.
Once I re-built the library, all things go smooth.

_Facepalm_ needed to run `git submodule foreach git pull origin master` **prior** to `make -j4`. After correcting that order of operations the code now runs just fine. Thanks to all the project contributors for making this code available.
@piiswrong Could you help me to rerun the test? Everything went well on my own branch
looks good. monitor is not in unit tests. Did you make sure that this works for python?
You can make a new pad operator. I'm not sure what happened in your case. Could you print out req[i] and check what it is?
To be clear, the only problem with ccsgd is pickle right? I'll try to fix it.

@piiswrong Yes, I printed something here https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/monitor.py#L44 and then add `Monitor(1000).install(exe)` after this line https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/autoencoder/solver.py#L75 , ran example/autoencoder/mnist_sae.py and it worked.

@piiswrong as I mentioned, `i` is `1` and `req[i]` is `kNullOp`. I can get around it by multiplying `data` by zero (effectively getting a vector of zeros), and get the behavior needed. But I am quite convinced that this is a bug in `mxnet`, because everything I do for the `input` variable I also do for `padding`, yet passing `padding` as the second argument leads to this issue, while passing something that is derived from `input` works.

Can you please comment on my second issue: does `mxnet` free up GPU memory as soon as model goes out of scope?
Is this backward compatible? Please keep mxnet-scala team informed on major changes and possible breaks. @yanqingmen @javelinjs

Ok. This is because pad doesn't require gradient. This should be an easy fix. In concat-inl.h: Backward, change CHECK_EQ(req[i], kWriteTo) to CHECK(req[i] ==  kWriteTo || req[i] ==  kNullOp) and when it's NullOp, don't propagate down the gradient. Would you like to contribute a PR?

It frees up memory when NDArrays go out of scope. You need to wait for operations from previous iter to finish (because they are pushed to engine queue async) before binding the next model. Try for arr in your_weights: arr.wati_to_read()

@tqchen @antinucleon  Maybe we should make GraphExecutor wait for all its operations to complete before destructing?
Yes. everything is float32 by default
Do you have dropout or other randomness in your network?

It seems the example contains dropout. https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/autoencoder/autoencoder.py

To my understand, dropout can generate same results in evaluation phase. In this experiment, I load pre-trained model from the same file, and the two machine generate different results.
Are you using is train in forward pass?
Close for now, because for hyperparameter, we have a full demo of CIFAR-100 example https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/notebooks/cifar-100.ipynb
@piiswrong First is pickle, it is easy, only need to add **getstate** to deal with pointer. The second is we only need to do weight decay on weight, this is a little headache for ccSGD

It turns out that the gnu linker is unable to find the symbols because in the Makefile, link flags are 'before' the object file mlp.o. So a small fix for reordering the LDFLAGS in the command line should be sufficient. Please apply this patch if useful. Thanks,

diff --git a/example/cpp/Makefile b/example/cpp/Makefile
index f8a8527..637c596 100644
--- a/example/cpp/Makefile
+++ b/example/cpp/Makefile

CC=g++
 mlp: ./mlp.cpp
  --      g++ -std=c++0x $(CFLAGS) $(LDFLAGS) -o $@ $^
  ++       $(CC) -std=c++0x $(CFLAGS) -o $@ $^ $(LDFLAGS)

 use_ndarray: ./use_ndarray.cpp
  --       g++ -std=c++0x $(CFLAGS) $(LDFLAGS) -o $@ $^
  ++       $(CC) -std=c++0x $(CFLAGS)-o $@ $^  $(LDFLAGS)
Ok, I'll fix this.

I have fixed SGD. According to Naiyan we should fix it

Relying on name still feels unreliable. Plus with this patch by default no weights will be decayed with custom model.

I made a mistake after Naiyan's review. By default if we don't pass arg_name in, there will be wd for all param. For custom model, I find a way to make pickle possible for distributed training, so maybe we can write custom sgd for custom model. I am going to fix the wd default bug now.

use `USE_BLAS=openblas` in your config.mk. if it dons't work, compile openblas from source. 

i tried centos a few days ago, it works well. here is the difference comparing to yours
1. i used centos 6.6
2. i failed to install gcc 4.8 from devtoolset-2, though devtoolset-1.1 works well but it only has gcc 4.7. so i build gcc 4.8 from source
3. i built openblas from source
It's probably better to make it work like lr_scale? instead of feeding in names, just feed in wd_scale and assign the scales in model?
@mavenlin @mli I added pickle which is able to pack classes but not test yet in distributed environment. Cloud you take a look whether it works?

@piiswrong It is a little bit mass currently, the final goal is to make optimizer aware each parameter, and use a special group of wd/lr/momentum/gamma/schedule for each one. However, the parameter is somehow related to symbol, and our optimizer is not symbol, which makes it a little headache.
closing for now, if need to be merge, please do a squash and merge

@antinucleon `self.kwargs["arg_names"] = arg_names` this is going to break other optimizers that doesn't have arg_names as argument. I think it should be moved to base Optimizer class as a set_wd_scale method.

code in evaluation:

try make clean_all
Was the original issue resolved?
thanks for your suggestion, but make clean_all does not solve the problem, the same compile errors prompt again.
Try make a fresh clone of the newest code and compile again.

yesï¼Œ my code is out of date. thanks, but i get another error:
'''
/usr/bin/ld: skipping incompatible /usr/local/cuda-7.5/lib64/libcuda.so when searching for -lcuda
/usr/bin/ld: cannot find -lcuda
'''
does mxnet not support cuda-7.5?
there are issues with singleton destruction in mxnet when your program shutdown before mxnet is fully initialized. Just add a time.sleep(5) at the end and it should be find.

is this an reproducible test on your side? This is likely due to problem during destruction, which should not pose a problem for normal training, but would be nice if you can use gdb to look into what is going on. 

Thanks
Normally it should be OK, as all the destructions are also scheduled, so things won't be freed until the related ops are completed

@tqchen The problem is executor.**del** returns before it's destruction is really executed. The next round will start pushing ops to the engine before the previous one finish. This makes manual synchronization necessary.
The del calls the destructor, whose destruction will be pushed to the engine, then next round ops are also pushed, and will follow the previous destruction if there is any dependency
What compiler did you use? I saw this once with `icc` #413
@vchuravy ,I used icc 16. However, using gcc 5.2 also generate other bugs.
I am using cuda 7.5, mxnet works well
so, any suggestion?

The concept of validation accuracy dropping is related to overfitting, which deep nets are exceptionally good at, so I'd be inclined to say this is normal. many people employ early-stopping to prevent this from happening. However, I've also been told that the validation accuracy rarely goes down on imagenet.

I will send a PR for the (req) == (kWriteTo) as soon as I finish a test for it, in couple days.

Wrt the freeing issue, I added some tracing and currently observe that in my particular case the memory is never deallocated. Most likely I accidentally leak refs to my ndarrays, I will post an update here if I narrow it down to an issue in mxnet. `wait_to_read` didn't help.

It seems to me that there's some kind of caching in place. Consider this example. ALLOCING is traced every time when `cudaMalloc` is called. `cudaFree` also traces when it is called, so it appears to be never called in this example:

```
>>> ctx = mx.gpu(0)
>>> def test():
...     mx.nd.zeros((100, 100), ctx)
...
>>> test()
[11:35:53] src/storage/./gpu_device_storage.h:40: ALLOCING 40000 0x700c09e00
>>> test()
>>> test()
```

Notice how after first  call to `test` the array is allocated, but not freed, even though it goes out of scope as soon as the function ends. However, when I call the function again, it doesn't allocate anything, so it reused the previously allocated memory. If I replace `zeros` with `mx.nd.array`, the behavior is the same.

Am I right that the chunks of memory are cached in some way? Can I disable this behavior? In my case I call the same function on different shapes, and therefore the cached memory is not reused and wasted, resulting in `Out of Memory` error

@piiswrong I tested misc.pickle has some problem when pickle optimizer. Ideally, it will pack code together with object, however when it involves heritage, it doesn't work. I will close this PR and send a new PR for the wd issue.
@tqchen I know this consistent, but it's causing OOM

have you installed the nvidia driver? libcuda.so is often located at

/usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libcuda.so
/usr/lib64/libcuda.so

I think it should be `kThreshold <= used_memory_ + size`. But yes, this is something we have been talking about fixing. We just don't have enough hands right now. You are definitely welcomed to fix this.
@antinucleon remember to move arg_names to the base class as a method. It's currently breaking all optimizers other than SGD
